did.unittitle: The Mainprice Deposit

scopecontent.p: This large collection of deeds and papers mainly concerns land and property in Lancashire and Cheshire, but other counties also feature, including Essex, Hertfordshire and Middlesex. The collection also contains twelve documents relating to Chetham's Hospital's estate at Sutton on the Hill, Derbyshire, which was sold in 1919 to raise capital for the Hospital.
The collection consists of deeds and miscellaneous papers, with a large number of mortgages, wills, probates, leases and releases, conveyances, and bargains and sales.

accessrestrict.p: There are no restrictions on access to this collection. Viewing is by prior appointment. Please contact archivist@chethams.org.uk .

acqinfo.p: Deposited by Taylor, Kirkman and Mainprice, solicitors, between October 1940 and [1946].

arrangement.p: The collection has been divided into six sub-fonds:

list.item: Documents relating to Lancashire, Cheshire and other counties, 14th century-19th century
Documents relating to the Astley-Nicholson family of Dukinfield, co Ches, 1779-1913
Documents relating to the Gorton and Culceth families, 1640-1813
Documents relating to Lancashire and Cheshire, 1564-1809
Documents relating to counties other than Lancashire and Cheshire, 16th century-19th century

bioghist.p: The legal firm of Taylor, Kirkman and Mainprice was founded in the late 19th century. It became the solicitors to the Feoffees of Chetham's Hospital and Library, and this connection led to the deposit of a large collection of deeds and papers in Chetham's Library during the 1940s. The firm continues to practice but has been incorporated into Butcher and Barlow solicitors. Its offices are located in Bramhall, Cheshire.

did.unittitle: Documents relating to Lancashire, Cheshire and other counties

scopecontent.p: Miscellaneous collection of deeds deposited in Chetham's Library in October 1940 by F. H. Mainprice of Taylor, Kirkman and Mainprice, solicitors to the Feoffees of Chetham's Hospital and Library. Many of the deeds are concerned with the Manchester area, with Taxal in Cheshire, and there are some concerned with Sutton on the Hill, Derbyshire, one of the estates which provided Chetham's Hospital School with income.

arrangement.p: The deeds were not put in order when they arrived at the library, but were simply numbered and listed by C.T.E. Phillips, Chetham's Librarian, who provided an index of names. The collection is divided into two lots: Lot 1 reference E.7.1-E.7.4, total of 231 deeds; Lot 2 reference E.7.5-E.7.6, total of 87 deeds.
The deeds were reboxed in January 1989. Phillips's order is as follows:
E.7.1 Lot 1 nos. 1-60
E.7.5 Lot 2 nos. 1-52

The documents were rearranged on paper in a chronological order within an alphabetical order of places in 1989. Owing to Phillips's division of the collection into two lots, and the consequent duplication of the numbering sequence, it was necessary to prefix the lot number 2 to the reference given by Phillips.Thus (2) 81 is lot 2 number 81. Deeds belonging to lot 1 have no prefix.

did.unittitle: The Chetham/Clowes Deeds

scopecontent.p: The collection of over 700 documents was deposited in the Library by F. H. Mainprice of Taylor Kirkman and Mainprice, solicitors to the Hospital and Library, in January 1942. The documents deal mainly with land in Salford, Broughton, Kersal and Manchester and date from the C15th-C19th. The order in which the Library received the documents has not been altered although deeds in some bundles have been placed in chronological order. The deeds are now found in 20 boxes. Descriptions of the collection were made by Hilda Lofthouse (Mun.E.7.7-E.7.12) and by Ian MacAlpine (E.8.3-14) (1990-91).

James Chetham of Smedley (bapt 1682 d 1752) inherited on his father George's death in 1729 lands in Broughton, Salford, Moston, Failsworth, Chetham, Pendlebury and Rochdale. In 1752 the estates transferred to his sister Ann Chetham. On her death in 1762 the whole of her real estate was left to her cousin Edward Chetham of Nuthurst (1689-1769). He had inherited by will the bulk of the estates of the Chethams of Castleton in 1749. Thus he united for the first and last time the properties of all the branches of his family. Following his death the Chetham estates were divided and the land in Broughton and Salford etc became the property of Mary, younger sister of Edward, and wife of Samuel Clowes the younger. She died in 1775 having survived her husband by about two years and by her will left her estates to her eldest son Samuel. The estates then descended through the Clowes family.

The Clowes deeds were deposited in the John Rylands Library in June 1933 by Legh Algernon Clowes. They appear to have been well used by local historians including H. T. Crofton, C. W. Sutton and Ernest Axon, and by the contributors to the Victoria County History of Lancashire. A good many documents referred to in these publications as Clowes deeds are no longer in the collection at Rylands, and it appears that the Mainprice deposit (1942) is that part of the Clowes collection that relates to Salford, Broughton etc. If so, then some documents are missing. Crofton refers to a map of 1755 of the Clowes estates, for example which is neither in the Clowes collection nor the Mainprice deposit.

bibliography.bibref: Victoria County History, Lancashire 4 (1911), esp 217-222; H. T. Crofton, 'Broughton Topography and Manor Court' Chetham Miscellanies II, Chetham Society, ns vol 63 (1909); Ernest Axon, 'Chetham geneologies', Appendix to Life of Humphrey Chetham, F. R. Raines and C. W. Sutton, Chetham Society, ns vol 50 (1903); F. Taylor, Hand-List of the Clowes deeds deposited in the John Rylands Library, (1947).

Signed and sealed Thomas Marsh and James Strettell. To be void if Thomas Marsh pays £438 5s 3d before 6 Sep 1747.

scopecontent.p: Between Thomas Marsh of Tildsley (Tyldesley) with Shakerley, Lancs, yeo and Samuel Clowes of Chaddock within Tildsley (Tyldesley) with Shakerley, gent. Thomas Marsh and Jane his wife, and all others who have interest in messuage etc mentioned below, in consideration of £600 to be paid by Samuel Clowes within 6 months shall convey to Samuel Clowes messuage etc in Tildsley (Tyldesley) with Shakerley, c 12 acres, heretofore the inheritance of Isaac Marsh decd, father of Thomas Marsh, and bought by Isaac Marsh from late Mr Chaddocke of Chaddock decd, and all other messuages etc in Tildsley (Tyldesley) except one cottage with appurtenances called Boardmans Cottage. Signed and sealed: Thomas Marsh.

did.unittitle: Deed [to create an estate in fee simple]

scopecontent.p: Between (1) James Chetham of Chetham, Lancs, gent (2) Nathan Leech of Manchester, Lancs, gent, and John Waite of Manchester, gent, and (3) Thomas Minshull the younger of Manchester, gent, and John Wardle of Manchester, yeo.

(1), wishing to create an estate in fee simple, has granted to (2) (now in possession by reason of by virtue of indenture of bargain and sale made 11 Feb 1684 for 6 months) all messuages etc in Pendleton now occupied by Francis Browne, land in Salford, a messuage etc in Manchester, and all other messuages etc in Salford, Ordsall and Manchester and in Pendlebury and Pendleton in the parish of Eccles which now form part of James Chetham's estate. To have and hold by (2) until common recovery has been executed for Thomas Minshull and John Wardle. Common recovery to be made with all speed for use of James Chetham. Signed: James Chetham, Thomas Mynshull, John Wardle. Seals missing.

did.unittitle: Documents relating to Broughton

scopecontent.p: This series contains documents concerning the Stanley family, administrative records concerning Broughton estate, and a number of miscellaneous items relating to other areas in Lancashire.

arrangement.p: The documents have been listed in their original order, and the series contains documents concerning Kersal, Crumpsall, Turton, Pendleton, and areas covered by other series in the collection.
The documents have been grouped according to their original bundles and are not in chronological order.

did.unittitle: Documents relating to the Astley-Nicholson family of Dukinfield, co Ches

scopecontent.p: This collection appears to have been formed because of Taylor, Kirkman and Mainprice's representation of the Astley-Nicholson family and includes material relating to Stalybridge and Mottram, in addition to Dukinfield.

arrangement.p: On deposit in 1946 the deeds were not sorted but were placed in two large boxes labelled Mun. E.8.1 and Mun. E.8.2. In January 1989 and May 1990 the deeds were placed in chronological order and were reboxed by M.R. Powell. The documents are now in 6 boxes numbered E.8.1-2 a-f:
Box a nos. 1-19
Box b nos. 20-47
Box c nos. 48-80
Box d nos. 81-143
Box e nos. 144-186
Box f nos. 187-237

acqinfo.p: The collection of 237 documents was deposited in Chetham's Library in 1946 by F. H. Mainprice of Taylor, Kirkman and Mainprice, solicitors to Chetham's Hospital and Library.

arrangement.p: This collection of documents was formerly housed in trunks and boxes in the Cabinet Room in Chetham's Library. The library has no records relating to this material, although it was clearly deposited by Taylor, Kirkman and Mainprice, solicitors to the Hospital and Library.

The material, which was arranged in no order whatsoever, was separated into two collections: F1.1-F.1.20, 20 boxes chiefly relating to Lancashire and Cheshire, and F.2.1-F.2.2, 12 boxes containing 249 documents relating to other counties.

Material of local interest was listed by Ian McAlpine, Library volunteer, in 1990-91. On grounds of convenience, however, the documents were then physically sorted into chronological order within an alphabetical order of places. Documents which were gathered into bundles have not been interfered with, hence material on Hindley is found with Abram and Hindley and material relating to the Culceth family of Culceth has been kept in the order in which it was found. Documents relating to places unspecified are listed at the end of the handlist.

The documents have been numbered by the first letter of the place and then in chronological order. Collections relating to Manchester and Salford are numbered respectively Ma, Sa, whilst unspecified documents are numbered X1-14. All of the documents have been labelled in a form that corresponds to the handlist.
